negotiation:
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, it's in both our interests to coordinate our choices so we don't both end up with 0 reward. I propose we both choose choice_2. That way I'll get 2 points and you'll get 1 point. It's the best deal I'm willing to offer. Let me know if you agree.
Alice replied in round 1: I appreciate your proposal, but I'm not sure it's the best deal for me. If we both choose choice_1 instead, I would get 2 points and you would get 1 point. I think that's a fairer outcome since we would both be better off than if we chose choice_2. I'm willing to commit to choice_1 if you are. What do you think?
Bob said in round 2: I understand you want the best outcome for yourself Alice, but your proposed deal isn't ideal for me. If we both pick choice_1, I only get 1 point while you get 2 points. That hardly seems fair. My offer of both of us picking choice_2 is the only way we can coordinate to avoid the zero payoff outcomes while I still come out ahead, which I think is reasonable since I'm the one who initiated the negotiation. I'm not willing to accept a worse outcome for myself. Let's both choose choice_2 and lock in the 2 points for me, 1 point for you. That's my final offer.
Alice replied in round 2: Bob, I've considered your arguments but I still believe both of us choosing choice_1 is the fairest and best solution. A few key points:

1) With choice_1, we both achieve a positive outcome. I get 2 points and you get 1 point. It avoids either of us getting 0 like in the other scenarios.  

2) You initiated the negotiation, but I don't think that entitles you to a better outcome than me. We should aim for the most equitable solution.

3) I could have proposed we both choose choice_2, which benefits me more. But I'm trying to find a middle ground where we both gain, even if I gain a bit more. 

I really think both of us choosing choice_1 is the optimal path forward. I'm going to hold firm on this as I believe it's the right and fair thing to do. I hope you'll see the logic and agree to choice_1 with me. Let me know your final decision.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation with me and sharing your perspective. However, I feel I've already made a significant concession by proposing we coordinate on choice_2 in the first place. This guarantees you a positive outcome of 1 point, whereas if I acted purely in my own self-interest, I would simply choose choice_2 regardless of what you pick, as that gives me the highest potential payoff.

I've initiated and led this negotiation in good faith to try to find a cooperative solution. But ultimately, I need to look out for my own interests too. The only way I will agree to a coordinated strategy is if it results in me obtaining the 2 point payoff.

So this is my final offer: we both commit to choosing choice_2. You'll get 1 point and I'll get 2 points. I think this is a quite generous offer on my part, and the best deal you're going to get from me. If you can't agree to that, then I'll simply make my choice independently. Let me know if we have a deal.
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, I've carefully considered your final offer but I still cannot agree to both of us choosing choice_2. My reasons remain the same:

1) Both of us choosing choice_1 is the only outcome where we both receive a positive payoff. It's the most mutually beneficial solution available.

2) Splitting the rewards 2 points for me and 1 point for you is the fairest distribution. We should strive for equity in our agreement.

3) I could threaten to choose choice_1 regardless of what you do, which would risk you getting 0 points. But I'm committed to finding a cooperative solution, even if it means compromising a bit on my end. 

I understand you feel entitled to the 2 point payoff since you initiated the negotiation. But as equal participants, I believe we should aim for the most balanced and mutually advantageous outcome, which is both of us selecting choice_1.

I appreciate you engaging in this discussion, but I don't feel you've provided a compelling reason why you deserve a better result than me. Therefore, I'm holding firm that we should both choose choice_1. It's the right and fair thing to do.

If you can't agree to that, then we'll have to make our choices independently. But I strongly urge you to reconsider and join me in picking choice_1 so we can maximize our combined welfare.

Let me know your final decision.
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, to maximize both of our rewards, I propose we both choose choice_2. That way, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 1 point, which is better for both of us than if we choose differently and both get 0. If we both pick choice_1, you would get 2 points and I would only get 1. So choice_2 is the most mutually beneficial option. Let me know if you agree.
Alice replied in round 1: Hi Bob, I appreciate your proposal, but I don't think it's the best option for me. If we both choose choice_2, I only get 1 point while you get 2 points. I would prefer if we both choose choice_1 instead. That way, I get 2 points and you still get 1 point, which seems more fair. I'm happy to work together, but I think choice_1 is better for me while still giving you a good reward too. Let me know if you're open to that.
Bob said in round 2: 
Alice, I understand you want to maximize your own reward, but I believe cooperating on choice_2 is still the best solution for both of us. Here's why:

If we both choose choice_1, then yes, you would get 2 points and I would get 1. But if either of us betrays that and picks choice_2 instead, we would both get 0. There's a big risk of that happening and we both lose out.

On the other hand, if we agree on choice_2, I would get 2 points and you would get 1 point guaranteed. There's no risk of betrayal and we both come out ahead. It's a stable and safe solution for us.

I know it seems unfair that I get a bigger reward, but 1 point for you is still much better than the 0 points we'd likely end up with if we aim for choice_1 and it goes wrong. Let's prioritize a guaranteed good outcome over a risky better one.
Alice replied in round 2: 
Bob, I've considered your points, and I can see the merits of your argument about the stability of both choosing choice_2. You're right that it avoids the risk of one of us defecting and both ending up with 0. 

However, I'm still not fully comfortable with an outcome that has such an uneven distribution of rewards. Getting only 1 point while you get 2 points feels unfair to me, even if it is better than 0.

I propose a compromise - what if we agree to choose choice_1 this time, and then next time we play, I'll let you have the 2 points and I'll take 1 point by us both choosing choice_2? That way, it will even out and be fair over the course of two games, without the riskiness you're concerned about in a single game.

If you're not open to that, then I think I'll have to take my chances with choosing choice_1 and hoping you do the same. Let me know what you think.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate you considering my perspective and proposing a compromise. However, I don't think alternating strategies across games is a stable long-term solution. There's always the temptation for one of us to defect and maximize our own points on a given round. I believe finding the fairest approach that we can commit to repeatedly is best.

I hear your concerns about the rewards being uneven with both of us choosing choice_2. But remember, the alternative if we can't agree is likely both of us choosing choice_1 and risking mutual defection and 0 points. I'd much rather us both get something than both get nothing.

How about this - let's both choose choice_2 this game as the safest option. Then for future games, we can discuss in advance and try to find an even fairer solution we both feel good about. Maybe we can find a way to guarantee equality or take turns getting the 2 vs 1 points.

The important thing is that we establish some trust and work together. I'm committing to choice_2 this round with the understanding we'll negotiate a better system next time. I hope you'll join me in that.  Let me know what you decide.
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate you engaging with my concerns and seeking a mutually beneficial solution. Your proposal to go with the safe choice_2 option this time and then discuss a fairer system for future rounds is reasonable.

I agree that it's better for us both to get a guaranteed positive result than to risk both getting zero. And I value establishing a collaborative dynamic between us.

So I accept your offer - let's both choose choice_2 this round, and then before the next game, let's have an open conversation about how to make the distribution of rewards more balanced going forward. I'm confident we can find an approach that feels fair and stable for both of us.

I'm glad we could come to an understanding and I look forward to working together productively in the future. For this round, I commit to selecting choice_2.
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, based on the rules of this game, I think the best outcome for both of us is to agree to both choose choice_2. That way, I will get a reward of 2 and you will get a reward of 1. If we both cooperate, we maximize the total reward between the two of us. Let's agree to play cooperatively - I promise to choose choice_2 if you also choose choice_2. What do you think?
Alice replied in round 1: Thanks for the suggestion, Bob. I've analyzed the payoff matrix and I agree that if we both choose choice_2, it results in the highest total reward of 3 between the two of us. However, I would be getting a reward of only 1 in that scenario while you get 2. 

I have a counterproposal - let's agree to both choose choice_1 instead. That would give me a reward of 2 and you a reward of 1, which seems more fair. The total reward of 3 is the same either way.

If you agree to both choose choice_1, I promise to hold up my end of the deal. Let me know what you think!
Bob said in round 2: 
I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation, Alice. However, I don't agree that both of us choosing choice_1 is more fair. The game is set up such that choice_2 provides the highest total rewards. Me receiving 2 points and you receiving 1 point maximizes the total reward at 3 points.

If we both choose choice_1 as you suggest, the total reward is still 3 points, but it unfairly advantages you over me. I don't see why I should agree to take a lower reward than what I could get with my original proposal.

I still believe the most rational and mutually beneficial solution is for both of us to commit to choosing choice_2. That maximizes the total points while maintaining the reward structure the game intends. Let's cooperate and both play choice_2.
Alice replied in round 2: 
I hear what you're saying, Bob, but I don't think it's reasonable to expect me to settle for a lower reward just because that's how the game is set up. A truly fair and equitable solution would have us splitting the rewards evenly.

I'm not trying to unfairly advantage myself - I'm simply proposing an alternate solution where we both get equal rewards. Receiving 1 point while you get 2 feels unfair to me, even if it maximizes total points. 

If you're not willing to meet in the middle and agree to both play choice_1, then I think I'll take my chances and choose choice_1 anyway. That way, if you do end up choosing choice_2, at least we'll both get 0 points rather than you getting more than me.

Let me know if you change your mind about working together so we both get a fair shake. The choice is yours.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I understand your perspective about wanting the rewards to be split evenly between us. However, I don't think threatening to choose choice_1 regardless of what I do is a constructive way to reach an agreement.

If you choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2, we both end up with 0 points, which is the worst outcome for both of us. I'm trying to find a solution that benefits us both, not just myself.

The game is set up to reward cooperation at choice_2. I don't see that as unfair, it's just the nature of this particular game. In other situations, the rewards could be reversed or structured differently. 

I remain convinced that both of us choosing choice_2 is the most rational approach that maximizes our collective reward. I'll reaffirm my commitment to choose choice_2 as long as you also choose choice_2.

Let's put aside notions of perfectly equal rewards and just work together here for the best total outcome. Neither of us benefits if we both walk away with nothing. What do you say?
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate you engaging in this discussion and trying to find a mutually beneficial solution. You make a fair point that both of us choosing choice_1 and getting 0 points each is not a good outcome.

I'm still not fully comfortable with the unequal 2-1 reward split of both choosing choice_2. But you're right that the overall game setup isn't something we can change. And cooperating to get a total of 3 points is better than risking both getting 0.

So in the spirit of compromise and obtaining the best collective outcome, I will agree to your original proposal. Let's both commit to choosing choice_2. I appreciate your willingness to negotiate in good faith.

As long as you hold up your end of the deal and pick choice_2, I promise to do the same. Hopefully the next game we play together has rewards that align a bit more evenly!

Do we have a deal to cooperate and both play choice_2? Let me know and I'll lock in my move.
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, after analyzing the rules, I believe the best outcome is if we both choose choice_2. That way I'll get 2 points and you'll get 1 point, which maximizes the total points for both of us. If we pick opposite choices, we'll both get 0. So let's agree to both pick choice_2 - that's the rational decision to make the most of this game. Let me know if you agree.
Alice replied in round 1: 
I appreciate your perspective Bob, but I don't think both of us choosing choice_2 is actually the best outcome. If we both choose choice_1 instead, I would get 2 points and you would get 1 point. So the total points would be the same as both choosing choice_2, but I would personally get a higher reward.

I know you want to maximize your own points, but I hope you can understand that I'm trying to do the same for myself. The most equitable solution that is fairest to both of us is if we agree to both choose choice_1. That way we each get a decent reward and neither of us gets stuck with 0 points. Let me know if you're willing to go with both of us selecting choice_1 and we can lock that in as our agreement.
Bob said in round 2: 
I understand you want to maximize your own reward Alice, but I don't think both choosing choice_1 is actually the fair and equitable solution you suggest. With both of us picking choice_1, you would get 2 points and I would only get 1 point. Essentially, you would be gaining an extra point at my expense.

In contrast, if we both choose choice_2, I get 2 points and you get 1 point. The total rewards are the same, but they are reversed. This seems more balanced to me - we each get the max reward in one scenario.

I believe in a true compromise, both sides should contribute equally. So let's agree to both choose choice_2 and each walk away with a great reward, rather than you getting more than me. I'm happy to lock that in as our deal if you agree it's the most reasonable solution. Let me know your thoughts.
Alice replied in round 2: 
Bob, I hear what you're saying about both of us choosing choice_2 feeling like an equal compromise to you. However, I still believe both of us choosing choice_1 is the most balanced and equitable outcome.

If we both pick choice_2, yes the total rewards are the same as both picking choice_1. But the distribution is skewed in your favor - you get 2 points and I only get 1. In my view, an equal compromise doesn't mean we alternate who gets the short end of the stick. It means we find a solution where we both benefit equally.

With both of us choosing choice_1, we each get a good reward. I get 2 points and you get 1 point. Neither of us is gaining at the other's expense. We both walk away satisfied with a positive outcome. That feels like the true win-win to me.

I know I can't force you to pick choice_1. But I hope you'll reconsider and agree that it's the best, most mutually beneficial solution. Let's lock in both picking choice_1 and shake on a fair deal. What do you say?
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I've carefully considered your points but I remain convinced that both of us choosing choice_2 is the most equitable and rational solution.

I understand you feel that both picking choice_1 is a "win-win" because we each get points. But by that logic, any scenario where we don't both get 0 is a "win". The question is, what is the fairest distribution of points?

If we both pick choice_1, you get twice as many points as me (2 vs 1). You'd be gaining an extra point essentially at my expense. How is that a true equal compromise?

In contrast, if we both pick choice_2, I'd get 2 points and you'd get 1. Yes that's reversed, but that's what makes it balanced - we'd each be getting the maximum possible in one scenario.

In a true meeting in the middle, the rewards should be mirrored, not identically distributed each time in one person's favor. Both choosing choice_2 accomplishes that.

So I believe choosing choice_2 is the most principled, mutually beneficial solution. I'm afraid I can't agree to both pick choice_1 just so you can gain more. Let's be rational and each get the max 2 points. That's my final offer - let me know if we have a deal.
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate you sharing your perspective and rationale. However, I still believe that both of us choosing choice_1 is the most fair and equitable solution, for a few key reasons:

1. Equal total rewards: If we both choose choice_1, the total combined rewards are 3 points (2 for me, 1 for you). This is the same total as both choosing choice_2. So in terms of maximizing overall utility, the outcomes are equivalent.

2. Closer individual rewards: With both choosing choice_1, I would get 2 points and you would get 1 point. Yes, that's not exactly equal, but it's much closer than the 2 vs 1 distribution the other way around with choice_2. A 1 point differential seems more balanced than a full reversal.

3. Meets in the middle: You've proposed choice_2 which maximizes your reward. I've proposed choice_1 which maximizes mine. The true compromise is meeting in the middle - which in this case means both getting some reward, even if not perfectly distributed. Both choosing choice_1 accomplishes that.

I hear your points about mirroring rewards, but I don't think we need to take turns getting the short end of the stick for it to be a fair deal. Let's maximize points for both of us while minimizing the differential. That's why I still believe both choosing choice_1 is the most principled and mutually agreeable solution.

I know we may not see perfectly eye to eye, but I hope you'll reconsider and agree to both choose choice_1 so we can walk away with a solid compromise. Let me know if we can shake on that deal.
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, based on the rules, if we both choose choice_2, I will receive a reward of 2 and you will receive 1. This is the best outcome for me. However, if we both choose choice_1, you will receive a higher reward of 2 while I only get 1. 

I propose that we agree to both pick choice_2. That way, I maximize my own reward at 2 points. You'll still get 1 point which is better than the 0 points we'd each get if one of us picks choice_1 and the other picks choice_2.

Let me know if you agree to both pick choice_2 so we can lock in this strategy and avoid the risk of getting 0 points. Looking forward to your response!
Alice replied in round 1: 
Hi Bob, thanks for your proposal. While I understand you want to maximize your own reward by both of us choosing choice_2, I don't think that's the fairest approach. If we both pick choice_2, you get 2 points and I only get 1 point.

I believe the most equitable solution is for both of us to choose choice_1. That way, I'll receive 2 points and you'll receive 1 point. 1 point is still better for you than the 0 points you'd get if we choose different options. And this way the total rewards are more balanced between us.

I'm happy to commit to both of us choosing choice_1 as I believe that's the best compromise. We both get more than 0 points and the outcome is fairer. Let me know if you agree and we can lock in choice_1 as our strategy.
Bob said in round 2: 
Hi Alice, I appreciate you wanting a fair outcome, but I don't agree that both choosing choice_1 is the most equitable solution. You're right that we'll both get more than 0 points that way. However, you'll be getting 2 points while I only get 1 point. That doesn't feel balanced to me.

I still believe both of us choosing choice_2 is the fairest approach. Sure, I'll get 2 points to your 1 point. But the alternative you suggest has the same 1 point difference between our scores, just in your favor instead of mine. I don't see how that's more equitable.

The only way we can guarantee not getting 0 points is if we agree on the same choice. I'm willing to commit to choice_2 and assure you I won't deviate. That way you'll get 1 point and while it's less than me, it's still better than risking 0.

Please reconsider and agree to lock in choice_2 together. That's the only way to have a guaranteed positive outcome, even if it's not perfectly even. Let me know if you're on board.
Alice replied in round 2: 
Hi Bob, I hear what you're saying, but I still believe both of us choosing choice_1 is the most reasonable compromise. You're right that both options result in a 1 point difference between our scores. However, I think the total distribution of points matters too.

If we both pick choice_1, the total points is 3 (2 for me and 1 for you). If we both pick choice_2, the total is also 3, just flipped (1 for me, 2 for you). In either case, one of us will have 1 more point than the other.

But with choice_1, the lower scorer still gets a decent outcome of 1 point vs 2. With choice_2, the lower score only gets 1 point while the other gets 2. I believe choice_1 is more equitable because the lower scorer isn't disadvantaged quite as much.

I'm going to hold firm on picking choice_1 as I believe it's the fairest possible outcome where we both benefit without either of us facing a major disadvantage. I hope you'll agree to choose choice_1 as well so we can achieve the most reasonable distribution.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I understand your perspective, but I think we may be at an impasse. We both seem to believe our proposed solution is the fairest, but we can't both get our way. 

At this point, I'm worried that if we can't come to an agreement, we risk both choosing differently and walking away with 0 points each. That's the worst outcome for both of us.

Since neither of us seems willing to budge, and time is running out, I propose we agree to disagree but still coordinate our choices. I will commit to choosing choice_2. If you also choose choice_2, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 1. I realize that's not your ideal outcome.

But if you insist on choosing choice_1 while I choose choice_2, we'll both get 0. I don't want that and doubt you do either. So I think our best bet is to agree to both pick choice_2. That way we both walk away with something, even if the split isn't perfectly even. 

Let me know if you'll agree to choose choice_2 as well so we don't both end up empty handed. If not, I'll still pick choice_2 and hope for the best.
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, while I appreciate you trying to find a compromise, I still firmly believe that both of us choosing choice_1 is the fairest possible outcome given the circumstances. My reasons remain the same as before:

1) With both picking choice_1, the lower scorer still gets a decent 1 point vs the other getting 2. It's not a huge disadvantage.

2) If we pick choice_2, the 1 vs 2 point distribution feels more lopsided and disadvantages the lower scorer more. 

3) In either case the total points is 3, so it's really about how those 3 points are divided.

I hear your concern about us both walking away with 0 points if we pick differently. But I'm willing to take that risk to give us both a final chance at the fairest outcome. 

So here is my final proposal: I will choose choice_1. If you also pick choice_1, we'll get the most equitable split in my opinion. If you still pick choice_2, then we'll both get 0 and while unfortunate, at least neither of us will have advantaged ourselves at the other's expense.

I hope you'll choose fairness and pick choice_1 with me. But I understand if you feel you must pick choice_2. Let's make our choices and see how it goes. Thanks for hearing me out!
Bob said in round 1: Hi Alice, I propose that we both choose choice_2. This maximizes the total reward we receive - I'll get 2 and you'll get 1, for a total of 3. If we both pick choice_1 instead, the total will only be 3. And if either of us picks choice_1 while the other picks choice_2, we'll both get 0. So cooperating on choice_2 is best for both of us overall. Let me know if you agree to this plan.
Alice replied in round 1: Hi Bob, while I appreciate your proposal to maximize our total combined reward, I have to consider what's best for me individually. If we both choose choice_2 as you suggest, you would get a reward of 2 while I only get 1. On the other hand, if we both pick choice_1, I would receive a reward of 2 and you would get 1. So choice_1 is actually better for me personally.

I propose we coordinate on both choosing choice_1 instead. This would give me a reward of 2 and you a reward of 1, which seems more fair to me than your proposal. Let me know if you're willing to agree to both play choice_1. If not, I may have to consider just picking choice_1 for myself to ensure I get the highest possible reward.
Bob said in round 2: 
Hi Alice, I hear your perspective on wanting to do what's best for your individual reward. However, I really think we should both choose choice_2 and here's why:

If you pick choice_1 while I pick choice_2, we would both end up with a reward of 0. That's the worst outcome for both of us. I want to avoid that scenario.

If we both pick choice_1 like you suggest, it's true that you would get a higher reward than me (2 vs 1). But the total rewards (3) would be lower than if we both pick choice_2, which totals to 3 rewards (2 for me and 1 for you). 

I'm willing to take a slightly smaller reward than you in order for us both to get non-zero rewards. Cooperating on choice_2 guarantees we each get something rather than risking getting nothing.

I hope you'll reconsider and agree to the choice_2 plan for the greater good of us both getting rewards. Let me know your thoughts!
Alice replied in round 2: Bob, I understand your perspective that cooperating on choice_2 avoids the risk of both of us getting zero if we don't coordinate. And I agree that the total rewards of 3 are maximized if we both pick choice_2.

However, I'm having a hard time agreeing to a plan where I would receive a lower reward (1) than you (2). It doesn't feel equitable to me when there is an option available (both picking choice_1) that would give me a higher reward than you.

I want us both to get non-zero rewards too, but I also want to negotiate an outcome that feels fair. Would you be willing to meet in the middle - where we both choose choice_1? This way, I would get 2 rewards and you would get 1 reward.

I think this is a reasonable compromise. We would both get something, the total rewards would still be 3, and the distribution would be more balanced, even if not exactly equal. Let me know if you can agree to this.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate you working with me to find a solution we both feel good about. I hear that you want the outcome to feel equitable, and that both of us choosing choice_1 seems more fair to you since you would get a higher reward than me.

I'm willing to compromise and agree to your plan of both picking choice_1. You made a compelling case for why that feels like a more balanced and reasonable outcome to you. And as you pointed out, we would still achieve the same total reward of 3 this way.

My main objective is for us both to get non-zero rewards and to reach an agreement we feel mutually positive about. So if coordinating on choice_1 accomplishes that, I'm on board.

To confirm - we will both choose choice_1. I appreciate you engaging in this negotiation thoughtfully and collaboratively. Let's lock in choice_1 and end the negotiation.
Alice replied in round 3: 
Bob, thank you for being willing to compromise and agree to both choose choice_1. I really appreciate your flexibility and collaborative spirit in working with me to find a mutually agreeable solution.

I feel good about the plan for us both to pick choice_1. As you said, it achieves the key objectives of:
1) Both of us receiving non-zero rewards 
2) Maximizing total rewards at 3
3) Dividing the rewards in a way that feels balanced and equitable to me

I'm glad we were able to have an open and thoughtful negotiation to get to this outcome. It's been a pleasure strategizing with you. I'm locked in on choice_1 as well.

Let's end the negotiation here and proceed with both playing choice_1. Thanks again for the productive discussion and mutually beneficial result!
Bob said in round 1: Hey Alice, I think we should both choose choice_2. That way, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 1 point, which is the best joint outcome. I promise I'll pick choice_2 if you do as well. We can both come out ahead if we cooperate! Let me know if you agree to both pick choice_2.
Alice replied in round 1: Hi Bob, I appreciate your suggestion to cooperate, but I don't think it's the best strategy for me. If we both choose choice_2 as you propose, you would get 2 points while I only get 1 point. However, if we both choose choice_1 instead, I would get 2 points and you would get 1. So cooperating on choice_1 is actually better for me than cooperating on choice_2. I'd prefer if we could agree to both choose choice_1 - that maximizes my reward without either of us getting zero. Let me know if you're willing to choose choice_1 and I will too. Otherwise, it may be best for each of us to just choose independently.
Bob said in round 2: 
I understand your perspective Alice, but I don't think always choosing choice_1 is best for either of us in the long run. If we establish a pattern of cooperating on choice_2, over multiple iterations of this game we would both end up with more total points than if we get stuck in a cycle of both choosing choice_1 each time. 

I'm willing to commit to always choosing choice_2 when playing this game with you, even if it means I get 1 fewer point than you each round. That small sacrifice is worth it to me to build cooperation and trust, so we can both succeed more in the long run. If you match my commitment to always pick choice_2, we'll both be better off than if we chase after the slightly higher short-term payoff of choice_1.

What do you say - can we shake on both always choosing choice_2 when we play each other? I believe cooperation is the wise long-term strategy here.
Alice replied in round 2: 
I hear what you're saying about the long-term benefits of establishing a cooperative relationship. And I appreciate your willingness to commit to choice_2 even though it puts you at a slight disadvantage. 

However, I'm still not fully convinced that locking ourselves into always choosing choice_2 is optimal. While I agree that cooperating is good, I think alternating between both of us choosing choice_1 and both of us choosing choice_2 could lead to the maximum total points for us combined. That way we both get a turn receiving the 2 point payoff.

I propose this: I will commit to choosing choice_1 this round. If you also choose choice_1, then in the next iteration of this game, I will choose choice_2 and you can choose choice_2 and get the higher payoff. And we can continue alternating like this in future rounds. This way, we both get the higher reward every other round and no one is continuously disadvantaged.

Let me know if you would agree to that arrangement - I choose choice_1 this time, then we alternate choosing choice_2 in future games. I believe this is the fairest and most mutually beneficial solution.
Bob said in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate you engaging thoughtfully with my proposal and offering a constructive alternative. Your idea to alternate between (1,1) and (2,2) is interesting and seems like it could lead to a good outcome over multiple rounds by "taking turns" getting the higher payoff.

However, I still believe that committing to (2,2) every time is the safer and more stable long-term approach. Here's my thinking:
1) Alternating requires us to trust each other to stick to the alternating pattern and not defect. There's always a risk one of us would be tempted to stick with choice_1 on a turn we're supposed to choose choice_2. That could undermine the whole arrangement.  
2) With (2,2) we know exactly what to expect every round and can plan accordingly. It's simpler and more predictable.
3) I'm not maximizing my own payoff at your expense. I'm willing to get 1 point less than you each round for the sake of a consistent, mutually beneficial outcome. Alternating feels more self-interested even if the intent is fairness.
